Introduction to vetoboxr

Frederik Tiedemann

2018-11-16

Source: vignettes/vetoboxr.Rmd
vetoboxr.Rmd

Vetoboxr makes spatial voting in R straight-forward. The process for simple voting setups is as follows:

1. Create Voters

To vote, you need to instantiate voters with a given position and role. Voters can be agenda setters (i.e. they make the proposal that is voted on), veto players (have veto power), normal voters or random voters. Random voters, unless otherwise specified, can take on all of the three other roles.

voter1 <- Voter(c(3, 4), role = "Veto")
voter2 <- Voter(c(1, 1), role = "Veto")
voter3 <- Voter(c(7, 3), role = "AS")

2. Create Status Quo

The other thing needed is a status quo, representing the current state of affairs. Once again, the constructor takes a position vector as argument.

sq <- SQ(c(2, 4))

3. Vote

To vote, simply call Vote().

vote <- Vote(sq ~ voter1 + voter2 + voter3, iter = 1)
names(vote)
#>  [1] "call"               "args"               "dimension"         
#>  [4] "voter_names"        "voter_count"        "voter_roles"       
#>  [7] "voter_position"     "voter_radii"        "coalitions"        
#> [10] "dimension_distance" "total_distance"     "status_quo"        
#> [13] "outcome"            "winsets"            "winset_area"

The vote, including status quo, outcome, voter positions and winset can also be visualized via plot().

plot(vote)

2D Vote

Developed by Frederik Tiedemann.
